data.text: How Often Do You Change the Chain and What about the Chain Rings?
Hello nomads! I have a question about your chains: how often do you change it? What about the chain rings? Happy travels to all!
Tool control chain wear not expensive.
data.author: Jesus Benito

data.text: bought a bike at Decathlon and today took it for a inspection (don't have enough knowledge to assess wear and miscellaneous issues). I was quite surprised that according to them it is necessary to change the chain, all the rear plates plus the front (with the "pedals"), the brake discs and pads. And I didn't even do 3000 km on the bike. I don't know how far the truth reaches and where the capitalist system begins.

data.text: I can't give you my opinion on what's happening to your bike, I'd have to see it. When a chain is not changed in time causing wear and deterioration of plates and pinons, the repair goes so far beyond a simple chain change. They say a chain has a life span of about 2000 km. I suggest you ask for an opinion in another workshop because the solution they propose is not cheap. Luck.

data.text: Buy a chain wear indicator. It will tell you. Tropical chain life for week maintained, multi speed chains is ~3,000 km. Some KMC variants kar upto 6 k km. Instead of going by distance, CV use the indicator. Plenty of videos by on YouTube on this. Parktool one is simpler. About replacing chain rings and cassettes - you'll need to go by visual examination. And, to if a new chain is slipping, it is an indication of teeth wear.

data.author: Giulia Juhé

data.text: pretty easy to find bike shops along the way. I figure out where the last good touring bike shop will be along my route and make sure things are OK with the bike before I head off into more remote places ie Istanbul before heading east to the Pamier Mountains (Tajikistan). You can always take links out of your chain if you really get into trouble, done that a few times. The spares I really take are fixing kits for my cooker, tent pole shim, extra hooks for my ortlieb panniers (suprising how many times tou break these). Bike stuff you can usually find along the way or at least a roadside bike shop that will find some fantastic way to fix your bike that you never even thought of.

data.author: Uknowho Ornot

data.text: Oh ok. It is not that if you use the chain till "end of life" as per the wear indicator, something comes to a standstill. No. It means, if you continue to use a written out chain, other parts wear out faster. That typically means the cassette and chain wheel. A very well cared for cycle and a lucky rider can expect that a cassette needs replacement at end of the 3rd chains life. And a chain wheel when the 3rd cassette comes to its end of life. Real life expectancy can vary. And this, if the chain is cleaned and lubed every 300 km or so. That would be 2 days if you are on tour. What I see is, people simply continue riding on and either do maintenance at goods shops, or replace the drivetrain or the whole cycle at end of a journey. At least, this is what I have seen in cases where i have closely followed a traveller. I guess such things loose importance while on the road that people rarely post about maintenance in SM / FB. But yes, if like to hear first hand.

data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Ideally I like to start with new cadette and chain, should last for 4 to 6 months. I just ride till they're all used up. Touring is at times also boring, for me, and searching for parts gives me something to do. Unless your in the middle of nowhere it not to difficult to find a chain and cassette. I think for touring it's better to have a cheap drivetrain, they are usually made of steal, heavier but more durable...

data.text: The chain changes depending on where you use it and how you use it. On asphalt and not much dust, mud or sand, I would change it every 3000 km.

data.text: I usually change when it rips, so at about 3500 km.
data.author: Alex Ring

data.text: Borrow a chain wear gauge. They have 2 measures, 0.5% & 0.75% (if I remember correctly). Replace the chain at the first wear measurement. If you miss it & go past the second wear measurement, then your sprockets are also too worn & should be replaced too.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: a chain checker might cost $25 . if you replace the chain at .05 , it doesn't wear the rings so fast , you know you need a cassette when the new chain won't mesh with an old cassette in the most worn gears , it will grumble and skip teeth . You know when the front ring is done when you pull away from a stop , the crank slips and you skin your shins .
data.author: Kevin Adams

data.text: I just had mine checked. Tool measured : 0.8- needs a new cassette and chain. Have done 6000km since new. Mostly on dusty/hard packed roads. Shimano GRX (canyon grizel) 6 months old
